```text
Welcome — thank you for contributing to HyperCode!

Our goal
HyperCode is built for and by a global community, with neurodivergent-first design as a core principle. This doc explains how to contribute, how we review, and how we make collaboration inclusive and sustainable.

Ways to contribute
- Report bugs: open an issue with reproduction steps and environment details.
- Propose features: open an issue labeled "proposal" with use cases and expected outcomes.
- Submit code: open a pull request with tests and documentation.
- Improve docs or examples: PRs that make the language easier to learn are highly valued.
- Accessibility & UX: share lived experience, test examples, or propose design changes.

Issue guidelines
- Use plain, concrete language and include reproducible steps.
- Include screenshots, short screencasts, or the smallest example that reproduces the problem.
- Add the "accessibility" or "neurodiversity-impact" label if the issue affects accessibility or cognitive ergonomics.

Pull request guidelines
- Branch name: feature/<short-description> or fix/<short-description>
- PR title: short, descriptive — "feat: add X" or "fix: Y"
- Include a short description of the change, motivation, and any migration steps.
- Link related issues with "Fixes #<number>" when appropriate.
- Add tests and update docs/examples as needed.
- Run the test suite and make sure CI is green before requesting review.
- Use the checklist in .github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md and add a short note about accessibility/neurodiversity impact.

Review process
- We aim to respond to PRs within 5 business days.
- Reviewers will focus on clarity, correctness, tests, security, and accessibility.
- If you need more time addressing review comments, leave a short status update on the PR.

Communication & accommodations
- If you need changes to the review process for accessibility or neurodivergence (e.g., longer review windows, different formats for feedback), say so in the PR or contact a maintainer privately.
- We expect everyone to act in line with the CODE_OF_CONDUCT. See that file for reporting.

Code style & testing
- Follow existing style in /src and examples.
- Add unit/integration tests for new behavior.
- Keep changes small and focused where possible.

Signing off
- Include a short "how I tested" section in the PR description.
- For large contributions, consider opening a design/architecture issue first to discuss approach.

Thanks for contributing — your work helps make HyperCode better and more inclusive for everyone.
```
